conversations.content: A Game of Cat and Mouse: Part One
Ebisu and Daikokuten were two dragons from Hinomoto—and for as long as anyone could remember, one had been chasing the other.
Day after day, Ebisu pursued  Daikokuten. He hoped that his attempts, however futile, would narrow the distance between them— that they might become friends.
But Ebisu's dogged—catted?—pursuit always left Daikokuten perturbed, and despite Ebisu's best efforts, they remained as distant as ever.
But one day, as the year drew to a close, Amaterasu, ruler of Hinomoto's dragons, issued a sudden proclamation.
The first 12 dragons to come and visit her at the beginning of the following year would be given important ranks, in the order they came calling.
Ebisu saw this as an opportunity. Were he to be chosen as one of the twelve, Daikokuten would surely be forced to acknowledge him.
The night of New Year's eve came, and dragons from all over Hinomoto rushed to see Amaterasu. Daikokuten was among them...but Ebisu was not.
On frigid nights, it is feline instinct to curl up at home...and Ebisu, ever the cat-napper, overslept. When he finally stirred awake and rushed to Amaterasu, disbelief took hold.
Daikokuten had been chosen as one of the twelve. Ebisu had long chased him, hoping to close the distance between them...but now Daikokuten was further away than ever.
Later, he began to hear rumors that their game of cat and mouse had made Daikokuten faster, helping him arrive at Amaterasu's shrine long before the other dragons.
Ebisu was so frustrated, he decided to pull a prank on Daikokuten...but his resolve failed him. This was all his fault. No amount of chasing could close the gap between them now.
Ebisu was no longer chasing him, but Daikokuten kept moving further and further ahead. Sadness and frustration rose within Ebisu's heart.
Years passed, until one day, a sulky Ebisu learned that Daikokuten would be delivering blessings to a foreign land as Hinomoto's representative.
All of the feelings Ebisu had been bottling up inside burst free. He couldn't forgive Daikokuten— and so he stole the blessings his rival was supposed to be delivering.
A Game of Cat and Mouse: Part Two
Ebisu had longed to become friends with Daikokuten, but the two of them only drifted further apart. In a final move of desperation, Ebisu stole the blessings Daikokuten was to deliver.
In the end, Ebisu was punished for his error, and scolded by people and dragons alike—Daikokuten  himself among the outraged.
To make amends, Ebisu agreed to help deliver the blessings. He spread happiness far and wide, drinking deep of it himself...and for the first time in ages, he knew peace.
Once the blessings had been delivered, a joyful Ebisu looked up at the moon. Suddenly, a lone figure approached him. It was Daikokuten.
Ebisu was shocked. It was the first time Daikokuten had come to him, rather than the other way 'round.
A sheepish Daikokuten looked away from Ebisu as he spoke. ＂There's something I've been meaning to apologize for...＂
It was that New Year's Eve so long ago, when they had competed to be the first to greet Amaterasu. Daikokuten had noticed Ebisu was absent, but hadn't gone back for him.
＂I should have gone and woken you up. I'm sorry.＂  But Daikokuten's apology fell on deaf ears.
It wasn't that Ebisu was refusing to listen. He was just too surprised by how little Daikokuten had changed.
All this time, he had been convinced the distance between them was too wide for him to ever catch up—and yet it was as if not a day had passed since Ebisu had started chasing him.
He finally realized that there hadn't been any real distance between them to begin with— and HE was the one who had turned his back on Daikokuten.
Ebisu couldn't help but laugh. ＂A-are you laughing? If you're gonna be like that, then I'm leaving!＂ ＂Wait! Wait!＂
Thus did the chase begin anew— but the two of them were content. Their relationship was the same as ever...and the game was once again afoot.
